text: Update on this: I ran the article by a few folks in our target audience and got some feedback. I also ran a heatmap/click report and got some useful info from that.

elements.text: Update on this: I ran the article by a few folks in our target audience and got some feedback. I also ran a heatmap/click report and got some useful info from that.

text: Conclusion: People are most interested in a specific section of the article and tend to skip over the rest. Users do tend to stay on the page longer, which may help us with rankings, but I'd still like to simplify the post or move ore of the extraneous stuff to the bottom.

elements.text: Conclusion: People are most interested in a specific section of the article and tend to skip over the rest. Users do tend to stay on the page longer, which may help us with rankings, but I'd still like to simplify the post or move ore of the extraneous stuff to the bottom.

text: <@UN29JC48H> We found that we could _add_ as much as we wanted to the end of it, but if we changed the beginning or the top couple of headers, the piece lost first-page ranking. But when we changed those elements back, it resumed its place.

text:
*Content marketing friends:* how useful do you find the "Top, Middle, Bottom of the Funnel" framework?

Is it something you use in your strategies? Are there any problems with it?

Would love opinions for an Animalz  article we're planning

elements.text: Content marketing friends:

how useful do you find the "Top, Middle, Bottom of the Funnel" framework?

Is it something you use in your strategies? Are there any problems with it?

Would love opinions for an Animalz  article we're planning

text:
Overall it's helpful and I've used it at every B2B company that I've worked at. The challenge is that some content will be useful at multiple stages of the funnel (e.g.. customer stories) so you have to be OK with that. Currently we think about stage of the funnel in addition to:
• Use case
• Persona

elements.text: Overall it's helpful and I've used it at every B2B company that I've worked at. The challenge is that some content will be useful at multiple stages of the funnel (e.g.. customer stories) so you have to be OK with that. Currently we think about stage of the funnel in addition to:
Use case
Persona

text: The other tricky thing for content marketers is that, often, bottom of the funnel actually means product marketing. So using that framework typically requires a strong relationship with product marketing (or content marketing being responsible for producing product marketing content at smaller orgs without product marketing which is a whole other can of worms). At PathFactory, we have 2 content marketers - one who sits on my team and one who sits in product marketing - who are responsible for opposite ends of the funnel and meet in the middle. Anytime there's a dispute about who should work on something, it's usually solved by agreeing on the purpose of the content and how it's going to be used in the buying cycle.

elements.text: The other tricky thing for content marketers is that, often, bottom of the funnel actually means product marketing. So using that framework typically requires a strong relationship with product marketing (or content marketing being responsible for producing product marketing content at smaller orgs without product marketing which is a whole other can of worms). At PathFactory, we have 2 content marketers - one who sits on my team and one who sits in product marketing - who are responsible for opposite ends of the funnel and meet in the middle. Anytime there's a dispute about who should work on something, it's usually solved by agreeing on the purpose of the content and how it's going to be used in the buying cycle.

text: I definitely believe, however, that we're going to need new ways to frame our content, though. Mature, sophisticated companies are increasingly blowing up their traditional funnels or moving towards running multiple funnels - one for acquisition and one for the customer lifecycle. Maybe a third if you're doing channel/partner marketing. When content from all corners of the org is being used for those strategies as well, TOFU MOFU BOFU starts to lose its meaning.

elements.text: I definitely believe, however, that we're going to need new ways to frame our content, though. Mature, sophisticated companies are increasingly blowing up their traditional funnels or moving towards running multiple funnels - one for acquisition and one for the customer lifecycle. Maybe a third if you're doing channel/partner marketing. When content from all corners of the org is being used for those strategies as well, TOFU MOFU BOFU starts to lose its meaning.

text: You may find it's pretty expensive.

elements.text: You may find it's pretty expensive.

text:
The idea of a funnel just doesn't fit modern buying behavior.

There's some interesting research by Gartner about the idea of "buyer enablement" - how buyers are researching on their own much further down the marketing/sales cycle, and companies need to start catering to the questions/decisions that their prospects and customers are trying to answer, rather than speaking to an internal sales process or "funnel".

I HIGHLY recommend watching this - it lays out a content framework that breaks out from the traditional 'funnel' mentality. <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gORR30CQuDs&feature=youtu.be|https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gORR30CQuDs&feature=youtu.be>

Somewhat related: Some of the challenges stem from a fundamental problem with the traditional idea of buyer personas—we have a bad habit of speaking to people's disposition, and not their situation. (see <https://corporatevisions.com/buyer-personas/|https://corporatevisions.com/buyer-personas/>)

attachments.title: Webinar: What About the Content?
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: Webinar: What About the Content?
attachments.video_html: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/gORR30CQuDs?feature=oembed&autoplay=1&iv_load_policy=3" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

attachments.title: Are Buyer Personas Sabotaging Your Sales?
attachments.text: For all the good intentions behind them, the typical model for B2B buyer personas might actually be sabotaging your sales. Here’s why.
attachments.fallback: Corporate Visions: Are Buyer Personas Sabotaging Your Sales?

The idea of a funnel just doesn't fit modern buying behavior.

There's some interesting research by Gartner about the idea of "buyer enablement" - how buyers are researching on their own much further down the marketing/sales cycle, and companies need to start catering to the questions/decisions that their prospects and customers are trying to answer, rather than speaking to an internal sales process or "funnel".

I HIGHLY recommend watching this - it lays out a content framework that breaks out from the traditional 'funnel' mentality.

text:
As someone newer to the content marketing scene, I find it useful as a theory but frustrating as a practice.

• when do you need to a post vs. sales page?
• related: which types of content are most effective for each stage? Not only in terms of keywords, but format and length and presentation. 
• where do you leverage constrained time and efforts if you can't tackle each part of the funnel every month? 
• what if (for newer startups) your positioning is still fuzzy and you're not entirely sure who your ideal customer is, let alone their stage?
• what about lower price points or scenarios where customers move through awareness and funnel stages rapidly? 
Someone in startup land used a mountain analogy recently and that made some sense to me--customers often climb up into a major decision not fall down into it--but it didn't (practically speaking) feel more useful than the funnel.

A major caveat is my understanding of "The Funnel" is limited. :grin:

what if (for newer startups) your positioning is still fuzzy and you're not entirely sure who your ideal customer is, let alone their stage?
what about lower price points or scenarios where customers move through awareness and funnel stages rapidly?

Someone in startup land used a mountain analogy recently and that made some sense to me--customers often climb up into a major decision not fall down into it--but it didn't (practically speaking) feel more useful than the funnel.

A major caveat is my understanding of "The Funnel" is limited.

text:
Funnel depends on the type of business. Freemium funnel is different from enterprise which  I'm sure is different than ecommerce/DTC (never worked in that sector).

I've been thinking more lately about funnels within a specific topic or topic cluster, rather than creating a catch-all funnel
